summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case. The order denies motions to quash a subpoena and compels the Administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program to produce materials to the court, setting deadlines for production and for the parties to propose a protective order.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20-CR-330) before the court. The order pertains to subpoenas issued by her defense.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge presiding over the case who issued this order, denying motions to quash and setting deadlines for document production.

persons.name: Administrator Feldman
persons.role: Administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
persons.context: The administrator of the compensation program who filed a motion to quash a subpoena and requested oral argument, which was denied by the court.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Ghislaine Maxwell and issued this order concerning discovery in that case.
Maxwell's defense issued a Rule 17(c) subpoena to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, which Administrator Feldman sought to quash.

events.title: Court Order on Subpoena Motions
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan denies motions to quash a defense subpoena issued to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and orders the program's administrator to produce responsive materials to the court.

events.title: Deadline for Document Production and Protective Order
events.description: The court sets a deadline for the Administrator to produce subpoenaed materials and for the parties to negotiate and submit a proposed protective order for the court's approval.

keyFacts: The court denied motions to quash a defense subpoena (Rule 17(c)(3)) issued to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and its administrator.
The Administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program was ordered to produce any materials responsive to Ghislaine Maxwell's subpoena to the court by November 24, 2021.
The court indicated it would review the materials first and might allow the parties to inspect them under a protective order to prevent trial delays.
The parties were ordered to negotiate and submit a proposed protective order for the court's approval by the same deadline (November 24, 2021).
